categories.name: Custom Rules
categories.description: The rules defined by your team appear here.

rules.name: api-name-doesnt-contain-api

spectralRule.body:
api-name-doesnt-contain-api:
  description: The API name must not contain the word API
  message: The info.title value "{{value}}" contains the forbidden word API
  severity: warn
  formats:
    - oas2
    - oas3
  given:
    - $.info
  then:
    - field: title
      function: pattern
      functionOptions:
        notMatch: /\b(api)\b/i

CUSTOM_SPECTRAL_GOVERNANCE_RULE_api-name.message: The info.title value "{{value}}" contains the forbidden word API
CUSTOM_SPECTRAL_GOVERNANCE_RULE_api-name.description: The API name must not contain the word API

rules.message: The info.title value "{{value}}" contains the forbidden word API

mitigation.description: The API name must not contain the word API

vulnerabilities.name: api-name-doesnt-contain-api

categories.name: Security Misconfiguration
categories.description: APIs tend to expose endpoints that handle object identifiers, creating a wide attack surface Level Access Control issue. Object level authorization checks should be considered in every function has access a data source using an input from the user.

rules.name: CORS Misconfiguration Rule 1
rules.message: Access-Control-Allow-Credentials is set as true and Access-Control-Allow-Origin is set as null. This could allow an attacker to send AJAX queries to a vulnerable website from a malicious page loaded by the victim's user agent. Even if a website with unauthenticated sensitive content (for example, an intranet website) doesn't allow authenticated AJAX requests, this misconfiguration still allows attackers to access it.

mitigation.description: If a web resource contains sensitive information, you need to properly specify the origin in the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header. You should only specify trusted websites that need this resource in this header, with the most secured protocol supported.

rules.name: CORS Misconfiguration Rule 2
rules.message: If the null origin is allowlisted, an attacker can use various tricks to generate a cross-origin request that contains the value null in the Origin header. This will satisfy the allowlist, leading to cross-domain access.

mitigation.description: If a web resource contains sensitive information, you need to properly specify the origin in the Access-Control-Allow-Origin header. You should only specify trusted websites that need this resource in this header, with the most secured protocol supported.

rules.name: CORS Misconfiguration Rule 3
rules.message: Access-Control-Allow-Origin is set as *. This means that the resource can be accessed by any origin.

mitigation.description: Make sure that sensitive data isnâ€™t available in an unauthenticated way (for example, by using IP address allowlisting). To enable the web browser to enforce the Same Origin Policy (SOP) in a more restrictive way, configure the Access-Control-Allow-Origin HTTP header to a restricted set of domains, or remove all CORS headers entirely.

vulnerabilities.name: CORS Misconfiguration

rules.name: Transport Security Rule
rules.message: The HTTP Strict-Transport-Security header is missing or isn't configured properly. This header informs browsers that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS and that any future attempts to access it using HTTP should automatically be converted to HTTPS.

mitigation.description: Add the HTTP Strict-Transport-Security header so the browser can remember that the site should only be accessed using HTTPS. You should also define the max-age property in the header..

vulnerabilities.name: Unencrypted communication

rules.name: Same Site Misconfiguration
rules.message: A cookie was set without the SameSite attribute. Without this attribute, the cookie can be sent as a result of a cross-site request. The SameSite attribute is an effective countermeasure to cross-site request forgery, cross-site script inclusion, and timing attacks.

mitigation.description: To have a robust defense against some classes of cross-site request forgery attacks, ensure that the SameSite attribute is set to either lax (good) or strict (ideal) for all cookies.

rules.name: Same Site None Misconfiguration
rules.message: A cookie with the SameSite value set as None isn't using the Secure attribute. This might allow an attacker to access the cookie by simulating a XSS attack on the client.

mitigation.description: To prevent the cookie with SameSite=None from being accessed by an XSS attack, use the Secure attribute.

vulnerabilities.name: Cross-Site Request Forgery

rules.name: Improper Cache Control Rule
rules.message: The Cache-Control header is missing or isn't configured properly. This allows the browser and proxies to cache content. This might be the intended behavior for static assets like CSS, JavaScript, or image files, but you should review the assets to ensure that sensitive content won't be cached.

mitigation.description: For secure content, make sure the Cache-Control header is set with no-cache, no-store, and must-revalidate. If an asset should be cached, consider setting the directives public, max-age, and immutable.

vulnerabilities.name: Improper Cache Control

categories.name: Excessive Data Exposure
categories.description: Looking forward to generic implementations, developers tend to expose all object properties without considering their individual sensitivity, relying on clients to perform the data filtering before displaying it to the user.

rules.name: Java Stack Trace
rules.message: The stack trace is exposed in the response body. This might reveal the structure of the application and any internal components it relies on. It might also reveal information like server-side file names and SQL code that the application uses, which could allow an attacker to fine-tune a subsequent injection attack.

mitigation.description: Send the user a more generic error message that reveals less information. Either suppress the stack trace entirely, or log it only on the server.

rules.name: Node Stack Trace
rules.message: The stack trace is exposed in the response body. This might reveal the structure of the application and any internal components it relies on. It might also reveal information like server-side file names and SQL code that the application uses, which could allow an attacker to fine-tune a subsequent injection attack.

mitigation.description: Send the user a more generic error message that reveals less information. Either suppress the stack trace entirely, or log it only on the server.

rules.message: The stack trace is exposed in the response body. This might reveal the structure of the application and any internal components it relies on. It might also reveal information like server-side file names and SQL code that the application uses, which could allow an attacker to fine-tune a subsequent injection attack.

mitigation.description: Send the user a more generic error message that reveals less information. Either suppress the stack trace entirely or log it only on the server.

rules.name: Python Stack Trace
rules.message: The stack trace is exposed in the response body. This might reveal the structure of the application and any internal components it relies on. It might also reveal information like server-side file names and SQL code that the application uses, which could allow an attacker to fine-tune a subsequent injection attack.

mitigation.description: Send the user a more generic error message that reveals less information. Either suppress the stack trace entirely or log it only on the server.

rules.name: Credit Card Data Leak in Response Body
rules.message: The response body looks like it contains sensitive information. An attacker could use this information to steal other user's identities or perform fraudulent financial transactions. This also violates payment card industry (PCI) security standards and most organizational compliance policies.

mitigation.description: Trim sensitive information from the response

rules.name: SSN Data Leak in Response Body
rules.message: The response body looks like it contains sensitive information. An attacker could use this information to steal other user's identities or perform fraudulent financial transactions. This also violates payment card industry (PCI) security standards and most organizational compliance policies.

mitigation.description: Trim sensitive information from the response

rules.name: UIDAI Data Leak in Response Body
rules.message: The response body looks like it contains sensitive information. An attacker could use this information to steal other user's identities or perform fraudulent financial transactions. This also violates payment card industry (PCI) security standards and most organizational compliance policies.

mitigation.description: Trim sensitive information from the response

vulnerabilities.name: Information Exposure

rules.name: Private IP Disclosure Rule
rules.message: The HTTP response body contains a private IP address (such as 10.x.x.x, 172.x.x.x, 192.168.x.x). An attacker could use this information to target internal systems.

mitigation.description: Remove the private IP address from the HTTP response body. For comments, use JSP/ASP/PHP comment instead of HTML/JavaScript comment which can be seen by client browsers.

vulnerabilities.name: Private IP Disclosure

rules.name: Information Exposure in query params key
rules.message: This request looks like it contains sensitive information in the URL. An attacker could exploit this sensitive information.

mitigation.description: Avoid using sensitive information like apikey, access token, auth credentials, username, password in URL as they can be captured in web server logs. Use body and headers for this information.

rules.name: Credit Card Data Leak in URL
rules.message: This request looks like it contains sensitive information in the URL. An attacker could exploit this sensitive information.

mitigation.description: Avoid using sensitive information like API keys, access tokens, auth credentials, usernames, and passwords in URLs since they can be captured in web server logs. Instead, use response body and headers for this information.

rules.name: SSN Data Leak in URL
rules.message: This request looks like it contains sensitive information in the URL. An attacker could exploit this sensitive information.

mitigation.description: Avoid using sensitive information like API keys, access tokens, auth credentials, usernames, and passwords in URLs since they can be captured in web server logs. Instead, use response body and headers for this information.

rules.name: UIDAI Data Leak in URL
rules.message: This request looks like it contains sensitive information in the URL. An attacker could exploit this sensitive information.

mitigation.description: Avoid using sensitive information like API keys, access tokens, auth credentials, usernames, and passwords in URLs since they can be captured in web server logs. Instead, use response body and headers for this information.

vulnerabilities.name: Information Exposure in URL
